Award.AwardTitle: The Impact of Standards-based, Traditional, & UCSMP High School Mathematics Curricula on Post-secondary Student Achievement, Course-taking Patterns, & Persistence in STEM C

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This investigation searches for evidence of the effectiveness of standards-based mathematics curriculum materials on postsecondary STEM achievement, course taking patterns and persistence compared to results from graduates who were exposed to other high school mathematics curricula. Approximately 30 postsecondary institutions in Minnesota and 30,000 students representing over 325 high schools are sampled. A retrospective cohort design and hierarchical linear modeling is used to quantify the longitudinal impact of curriculum type on postsecondary STEM performance. Results will help educators, school districts, students, parents and academicians to make more informed decisions about appropriate mathematics curricula for their student population.

Introduction:

 

In the early 1990’s, after a long series of disappointing results on national and international mathematics achievement tests (i.e. TIMSS, NAEP, A Nation at Risk), with disappointing numbers of students pursuing four full years of high school mathematics, and disappointment with the number of US citizens who pursued a STEM major in college and subsequently entered STEM related careers, the National Science Foundation (NSF) funded the development of 13 complete mathematics programs at the elementary, middle grades and secondary level in a large scale attempt to improve the quality of the nations’ K-12 mathematics programs and ultimately to interest a wider variety of students to complete four years of college intending mathematics while in high school.

 

The Minnesota Mathematics Achievement Project (MNMAP) was a four-year program of research (2007-2011) that explored the relationship between high school mathematics curricula and college-level mathematics performance.  Specifically, MNMAP contrasted three secondary level NSF-funded curricula (Contemporary Mathematics in Context (Core+), Mathematics Modeling Our World (MMOW) and the Interactive Mathematics Project (IMP) with various commercially developed (CD) textbook programs (i.e.  Addison Wesley, Harcourt, Saxon etc.) and the University of Chicago School Mathematics Project (UCSMP), a program partially supported with NSF funds.  The first editions of the three NSF funded secondary curricula examined here were published for general use between 1997 and 1999.  Second editions of these programs were released for general use approximately ten years later.

 

Of most interest was the high school mathematics curricula used by students (NSF-funded or not).  The student level variables used in the analyses were: ACT scores, grades in high school mathematics (GPA), number of years of high school mathematics (3, 4 or 5), ethnicity, and gender.

The outcomes of most interest were students’ college level mathematics achievement, persistence (# of courses completed), and course taking patterns over as many as eight semesters of college work.  This program of research whose data is based on college records and transcripts has to date conducted over a dozen studies that for the most part addressed progressively more complex questions about this relationship.  Each study has resulted in a formal research paper.  Seven of these papers have been published; the others are either in press or have been submitted for review.  Versions of each of these papers can be found on the project website early in 2012.  www.cehd.umn.edu/ci/mnmap
